author_bibliography.author: David Hume
author_bibliography.description: David Hume was a Scottish philosopher, historian, and essayist who became one of the most influential figures of the Enlightenment. Known for his radical empiricism and philosophical skepticism, Hume profoundly shaped modern debates on knowledge, morality, religion, and personal identity. His works challenged traditional metaphysics and inspired later thinkers such as Kant, Mill, Darwin, and contemporary philosophers of mind and science.
author_bibliography.background: Born in Edinburgh, Hume was a precocious student who left university early and pursued a program of rigorous self-study. Though his early work, 'A Treatise of Human Nature', was initially dismissed, it became one of the foundational texts of modern philosophy. Hume's clear prose and critical stance on reason, causation, and religion set him apart from both rationalists and dogmatic theologians. Later in life, he gained popular acclaim for his historical and political writings, even while remaining controversial for his philosophical ideas.

works.title: A Treatise of Human Nature
works.original_title: A Treatise of Human Nature: Being an Attempt to Introduce the Experimental Method of Reasoning into Moral Subjects
works.summary: Hume’s most comprehensive philosophical work, this book attempts to build a 'science of man' based on empirical observation and psychological insight. It is divided into three parts: understanding, passions, and morals. Key ideas include the theory of impressions and ideas, skepticism about causality, the denial of a permanent self, and the foundation of morality in sentiment. Though initially overlooked, it is now regarded as a cornerstone of Western philosophy.

works.title: An Abstract of a Book Lately Published
works.original_title: An Abstract of a Book Lately Published: Entitled A Treatise of Human Nature
works.summary: This short pamphlet was Hume's attempt to promote the Treatise after its initial poor reception. It summarizes key arguments from the Treatise, especially his views on ideas, impressions, and belief. While of limited circulation at the time, it provides a valuable insight into how Hume saw the central claims of his major work.

works.title: Essays, Moral and Political
works.summary: These early essays cover a wide range of subjects, including economics, politics, aesthetics, and morality. They reflect Hume’s interest in making philosophy accessible and practical. The essays helped establish his reputation as a man of letters and remain valuable for understanding Enlightenment thought.

works.title: An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding
works.summary: A refined and more accessible version of parts of the Treatise, this work contains Hume’s most famous arguments: the problem of induction, the denial of rational justification for miracles, and his account of belief as a feeling rather than a rational act. It presents a central challenge to rationalist metaphysics and remains foundational in epistemology.

works.title: An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals
works.original_title: An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals
works.summary: In this second Enquiry, Hume articulates a sentimentalist ethical theory, arguing that moral judgments are rooted in human feelings rather than reason. He explores the role of utility, virtue, and sympathy in morality. The work is more optimistic and refined than the third book of the Treatise and is considered by Hume to be his best philosophical writing.

works.title: Political Discourses
works.summary: This collection includes essays on commerce, taxation, money, and political stability. Hume displays early liberal economic views and anticipates key ideas of later economists like Adam Smith. The essays were widely read in France and had a significant influence on Enlightenment political economy.

works.title: The Natural History of Religion
works.summary: Hume examines the psychological and sociological origins of religious belief. He argues that polytheism, not monotheism, was humanity’s first religion, born of fear and ignorance. The work is notable for its naturalistic and skeptical tone, anticipating anthropology of religion and later secular critiques.

works.title: Four Dissertations
works.summary: This volume includes 'Of the Standard of Taste,' 'Of the Passions,' 'Of Tragedy,' and 'The Natural History of Religion.' These essays explore aesthetics, emotion, and human nature with clarity and subtlety, reinforcing Hume’s reputation as a refined thinker concerned with the human condition in both reasoned and artistic life.

works.title: Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion
works.summary: Published after his death, this dialogue presents a fictional conversation between three characters debating the existence and nature of God. Through the skeptical character Philo, Hume critiques traditional arguments for God's existence, especially the design argument. The Dialogues are celebrated for their literary and philosophical depth and remain central in the philosophy of religion.

works.title: The History of England
works.original_title: The History of England from the Invasion of Julius Caesar to the Revolution in 1688
works.summary: Hume’s most commercially successful work, this six-volume history covers British politics, monarchy, and culture. Written in an accessible and elegant style, it emphasizes empiricism and rational analysis over religious or partisan narratives. The work shaped British historical understanding for decades and established Hume as a respected historian.

early_period.characteristics: 1739-1748 Experimental, bold, and skeptical tone; attempt to found a 'science of human nature'; strong influence of Locke, Berkeley, and Newton
early_period.themes: Empiricism, causation, impressions and ideas, critique of self, foundations of ethics, problem of induction

middle_period.characteristics: 1748-1757 Popular essays and more accessible summaries of philosophical ideas; growing literary reputation and public engagement
middle_period.themes: Ethics and sentiment, critique of religion, political economy, human nature, aesthetics

late_period.characteristics: 1757-1776 Mature literary style, historical writings, philosophical dialogues, and reflections; philosophical clarity mixed with political caution
late_period.themes: Natural religion, political skepticism, critique of miracles, toleration, historical analysis, secular moral theory

major_themes: Empiricism and the origin of ideas
Critique of miracles and natural religion
author_bibliography.influence: David Hume influenced nearly every area of modern philosophy and social science. Kant credited Hume with awakening him from his 'dogmatic slumber'. Hume's empiricism shaped analytic philosophy, while his skeptical arguments laid the groundwork for modern epistemology, philosophy of mind, and cognitive science. His naturalistic ethics prefigured utilitarianism and moral psychology. His political and economic essays influenced Enlightenment thought and liberal institutions, while his religious skepticism had a profound cultural impact.
author_bibliography.note: This bibliography focuses on Hume’s major published works and their philosophical significance. His letters, unfinished manuscripts, and editorial revisions (such as in different editions of the Treatise and the Enquiries) provide additional insight into the development of his thought.
